header.title: The Scroll of Set - Issue Number 13, Volume II-1

central_thesis: This edition of The Scroll of Set articulates foundational Setian principles, emphasizing the Temple of Set's role as an elitist organization dedicated to individual and civilizational survival through conscious self-evolution (Xeper). It establishes the Temple's non-partisan political stance, advocating for individual agency and the preservation of religious freedom, while distinguishing Setianism's independent path from concepts of universal harmony.

structure_content.chapter_title: Non-Partisan Political Aspects of the Setian Philosophy
structure_content.summary: This article outlines the Temple of Set's official non-partisan political policy, citing tax-exempt status and the desire to avoid internal division over 'trivial matters' as reasons. It stresses that Setians, as an elite, must ensure their own survival and contribute to civilization's betterment, not by lobbying, but through individual intelligence and action. The core Setian challenge is to succeed in bringing forth a 'glorious age with purpose and knowledge' (Xeper), achieved by foresight and anticipation rather than blind grappling with the present. It also highlights the importance of religious freedom for the Temple's existence and rejects the notion of universal salvation, focusing on the survival of the 'few'.

From a Setian and nursing perspective, this article discusses death as a potential 'comforting boon.' It criticizes the medical compulsion to sustain life indiscriminately, particularly when quality of life is severely diminished. The author reflects on past experiences, asserting that a Setian approach respects individual dignity and the 'Will' in accepting the body's decay, encapsulated by the affirmation 'The Will still lives. Xeper,' contrasting this with a Christian view of Hell.

Written by an Honorary Setian, this article details the lifelong passion and extensive collection of science fiction by Forrest J Ackerman. While not directly philosophical, it implicitly supports Setian values of individual pursuit of knowledge, vision (speculative futures), and dedication to a personal 'way of life,' viewing the collection as a form of immortality and anticipating future revivification through cryonic preservation.

This brief update announces the reappointment of key leadership figures within the Temple of Set's Council of Nine, including Magister Robert Ethel as Chairman and Magistra Margaret Wendall to a nine-year term. It serves to inform members of the organizational structure and continuity of leadership.

This section reviews two science fiction novels, 'The Siege of Wonder' and 'Missing Man,' recommending them to Setians for their 'messages' and 'sheer reading pleasure.' The reviews highlight themes relevant to Setian philosophy, such as the conflict between cold rationality (science) and the magical art (Will/Intuition), the balance between power and motive, and the importance of self-awareness and understanding one's deepest desires. The author praises the books for illustrating the sociopsychology of magic within well-crafted narratives.

A letter from Robert G. Brink II° addresses potential misunderstandings of Setian philosophy, specifically clarifying that a 'Setian is not in harmony or oneness with the universe.' It emphasizes that Set has given a 'Gift which is independent of the natural order,' differentiating Setianism from philosophies of cosmic unity and reinforcing the distinct, independent nature of the Setian path. The author stresses the importance of precise language to avoid confusion among members and outsiders.

key_concepts.definition: An elitist, tax-exempt religious organization dedicated to the survival and advancement of its intelligent, gifted, and visionary membership, and by extension, civilization. It operates on principles of individualism and self-reliance, distinct from partisan politics.

A central Setian term, derived from ancient Egyptian, meaning 'I have come into being' or 'I will come into being.' In this context, it represents the goal of self-deification through continuous self-evolution, purpose, and knowledge, where the individual Will persists beyond physical death. It implies a conscious process of becoming and self-creation, distinct from merging with a universal whole.

Individuals who possess talent, gifts, vision, and intelligence, distinguishing them from the 'masses.' They are expected to lead, act independently, and prioritize their own survival and prosperity, seeking a 'glorious age with purpose and knowledge'.

The Temple of Set's policy of refraining from direct involvement in partisan political activities (lobbying, endorsements) due to its tax-exempt status and the philosophical conviction that individual Setians should exercise their own intelligence and Will to address political issues affecting them, rather than relying on the Temple for guidance.

Referenced in the letter to the editor, this refers to a unique endowment from Set, described as 'independent of the natural order.' It signifies the distinct and autonomous nature of the Setian path, explicitly rejecting concepts of universal harmony or oneness with the cosmos, and underscoring the individual's separation and self-creation.

The inherent drive and consciousness of the individual, central to Setian philosophy. It is asserted that the Will 'still lives' beyond bodily decay, enabling the process of Xeper. It is the guiding force for individual action, self-evolution, and resistance to external pressures.

practical_system.description: While not a grimoire of specific magical operations, this newsletter outlines the core philosophical and ethical system for operative Setian practice. The 'system' is primarily one of conscious self-evolution and strategic living. Setians are encouraged to cultivate intellect, foresight, and individual Will to ensure their own survival and prosperity. This involves proactive problem-solving, independent thought, and a commitment to self-mastery, with the ultimate goal of Xeper—the continuous coming into being of the individual's perfected form, where the Will persists. Practical application involves discernment in political engagement (acting lawfully and intelligently for personal interest, not as a political club), embracing the 'Right to Die' with dignity when the Will dictates, and critically evaluating external information (like science fiction themes) through a Setian lens. The emphasis is on internal transformation and the manifestation of a distinct, independent self, guided by the Gift of Set, rather than prescribed rituals or tools.

relevant_quotes.text: We are an elitist organization; we realize that not all people are truly equal, but are indeed unique.
Our first duty, however, is to ensure our own survival and prosperity.
The Temple of Set does not involve itself in partisan political activities; it will not lobby, endorse candidates or issue political position papers.
However, if we do succeed, then we shall come into a most glorious age with purpose and knowledge. That, indeed, is our challenge: to succeed.
The Setian should take it upon himself to do his part to solve the problems that threaten us, so that mankind can go on.
Now I say as a Setian: Let the body return to decay and dust. The Will still lives. Xeper.

A Setian is not in harmony or oneness with the universe. I understand that a I° Setian might not be aware of a real Prince of Darkness, Set, who has given us a Gift which is independent of the natural order, and I do not mean to sound sarcastic nor to imply that I know all there is to know about being Setian, but I do know what being Setian is not.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of The Scroll of Set is highly relevant for understanding the foundational philosophy and operational principles of the Temple of Set in its early years (1976). It clearly delineates the organization's unique stance on political engagement (non-partisan), individual responsibility, and the nature of Setian self-deification (Xeper). By emphasizing independence, elitism, and a proactive approach to one's own destiny and the future, it positions Setianism as a distinct path of conscious evolution, explicitly differentiating itself from doctrines of universal oneness. The articles collectively reinforce the idea that Setian magic is primarily an internal, intellectual, and volitional process leading to the manifestation of individual Will and potential, rather than external ritual work (which is not detailed herein).
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of existing members of the Temple of Set, particularly those in various degrees of initiation (I°, III°, IV°), as well as potential aspirants. The newsletter serves to clarify core doctrines, provide organizational updates, and reinforce the Setian worldview, ensuring a consistent understanding of its philosophical tenets and practical implications for self-development and interaction with the wider world. The letter to the editor explicitly addresses the need to prevent misunderstandings about Setian principles, indicating an internal focus on ideological clarity.
